>>91126726
I used to make bong/bubblers with those and sold them to college kids at university of Maryland. Drill into a empty liquor bottle at and angle with a glass bit, under water the whole time. Use a water safe non toxic epoxy to hold the pipe in place at about a 45° angle. Then you could screw own size adaptors like in that anons image and place a screen in it and you have a bowl. You can then pack multiple bowls by screwing on more fittings. It was novel. Wish I had pictures but it was long ago and I don't think I have any left.

idk what country youre from but i assume its eu wide now.
the situation used to be everything that was below 22 euros was exempt from import tax and fees.
new eu wide law is that everything you order outside the eu needs to be taxed (some webstores like ali already include this in the displayed price) but all items below 150 euros dont have any import fees.
in most cases this is actually cheaper and a better system compared to the previous if you buy electronics which are over 22 euros.

TLDR: new laws require you to pay tax on any item shipped from outside the eu but no import fees will be charged for items up to 150 euro which in most cases ends up being cheaper for the consumer if you order items that are 22 euros or more

>>91104495
>What's the worst that can happen with a shitty cable?
Higher resistance due to thin copper cables so slower charging because of losses. I'll be fine for data transfer or whatever. Some phones have problems with shit charging cables due to these losses. The longer the cable the higher the losses and 2 meters are considered "long" for low voltage power delivery, remember it's actually 4 meters of cable in total, there and back (positive and negative wire). These chink cables are usually cheap because they use thin copper wires that are just about adequate.
Other than that you'll probably be fine.
>>91106378
If the cable isn't getting hot in half an hour to an hour at max load you'll probably be fine. I've recently used underrated chink cables for my electronics projects and at worst they just get nice warm, but I'll be adding a both an current fuse and a thermal fuse just in case to prevent thermal runaway.

>>91110128
I'm not the anon you were replying to by the way, I simply couldn't resist making the joke. But I do wear glasses myself for over 25 years now.

>anyway, how "safe" are those cleaners? a few threads ago some Anon said the cleaner broke his glasses
There are two potential and easily avoidable issues with using ultrasonic cleaners for glasses. The first is the risk of scratching up the lenses beyond repair. This happens the moment you have the cleaner running and allow the lenses to touch the walls of the cleaner, or when you have other loose items or hard debris in it. These scratches happen near instantly and pretty much can't be fixed. The second issue comes from using aggressive cleaning solutions which eat away at coatings, glues or acrylic frames. Mild hand soap is about as harsh you want to go for regular cleaning, diluted blue spirits is what opticians use but should never be used regulary as it will eat away at coatings. But all of this is assuming you're buying a proper ultrasonic cleaner, and not some bullshit Chinese plastic tub with a N64 rumble pack pressed against it.

Personally I just use tap water to rinse of dirt and a clean microfiber cloth for my daily cleaning. If that's not enough I'll use a Zeiss wet wipe or blue spirits diluted with demineralised water if things are really bad. I need new glasses every 2 to 3 years on average due to my still deteriorating eyesight and cleaning like has never caused me to scuff or scratch up my glasses. Don't overthink cleaning your shit, they're just glasses.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Fiftyseven ESIS model kit (€30)
As promised in >>91074157, a full review now that I've build the kit. For this build I used DSPIAE nippers, Revell needle tip plastic cement, Olfa hobby knife blades, and black and brown Gundam panel liners.

Included in the box are runners made of quality hard plastics that don't get stress marks easily, multiple sets of 1x2mm water slide decals for the eyes, and the build manual. The build itself was straightforward with clear 3D lined instructions. You start with the core/inner frame, but just like with the robomaid Yui kit you have to disassemble the head and forearms and replace them with the actual armored pieces. I simply skipped those parts of the core to save time. All pieces are snap-on or slide-in, but some smaller pieces such as the red pearl, thighs and sphinx's beard fall off easily during handling. You can be patient and keep reattaching those items or just glue them in place like I did.

Articulation is surprisingly nice. There are ball joints in the head, lower back, upper legs, shoulders, feet and hands. The knees are double jointed allowing for a full 180 bend. The elbows are basic hinge joints. Finally there are also swivel joints in the the upper arms and upper legs allowing for rotation on top of the ball joint movement.

In terms of accessories you get a floor and a backdrop, a throne, 3 weapons, wings for Esis which you can also fold up and attach to the throne, and a transformable sphinx/sarcophagus. You can also replace the spinx's head with the upper torso of Esis if that's your thing. The floor and backdrop can be reversed with one side being robo-egyptian themed and the other being the default style from the other Fiftyseven kits. All in all, I'd say this kit was definitely worth it despite it's small size. The robomaid Yui kit felt lackluster as it focused more on clothing options, where this Esis focuses more on aesthetics and accessories.

8/10, can't wait to see what robowaifu they release next.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91119909
>Is the color really this different? Or did we kinda get chinked this time?
It does look more golden-yellow in real life than the golden-orange from the product previews. But I don't mind it, the glossy plastic with some marbling still sells the gold effect it's going for.

>damn, i used a nail nipper and thats all for my yui lmao. How do i avoid damaging them when cutting? do i need any of these fancy things?
Quality nippers allow you to neatly remove parts from the runner (sheet of parts). Often these cuts will be barely visible, if visible at all. To achieve a perfect cut you want to cut each part twice. The first cut 2mm away from the part, the second flush to the part. This greatly reduces the risk of getting stress marks (ie plastic turning white) and nubs (remaining pieces of runner on part).

Hobby knives are mostly just nice to have to clean up cuts gone wrong or remove accidental nubs. Any cheap set will do, I just prefer Olfa blades as they are sharp as fuck and hold their edge.

Plastic cement is not required to build this kit. I just didn't had the patience to deal with the parts that repeatedly came off and already had it laying around from previous builds.

Panel liners are an easy way of adding depth and shadows to parts by tracing edges and grooves and then wiping off excess ink. The effect is pretty noticeable when you compare the pictures. Fineliners and pencils can achieve a similar effect but don't play nice with all plastics so do try it on a spare part or on the inside of a part.

In the end it's all up to you and how far you want to take things. I too once started with nail clippers and slowly purchased nicer tools and new techniques as I got more into model kits and started buying expensive kits. But if I had to recommend one item if you intend on building more kits, it would definitely be the nippers.

>Mine arrived but i'm waiting for the weekend so i can do it in peace, once again...
Enjoy your build anon!

I got new brakes a few months ago https://m.aliexpress.com/item/4000012057990.html which work well but it was a pain to install them on the vintage Peugeot UO-8. I tried the cheapest metal pedals (<20CAD) and they broke within a few months. They didn't refund that because they thought it was damaged in shipping.
I tried a 9 speed chain. The quick link included cracked. They refunded it.
I tried pic related lights. The rear light doesn't stay on. The front light is fine if a bit weak.

posts.com:
>I'm getting the acrylic anime waifu as well
edition

How to request advice:
>Budget
>Kind (in-ear or earbuds)
>Intended use
>Sound signature (or genres you like)
>Past gear and your thoughts on them

FAQs:
>Do I need a DAC/dongle?
Only if your source: lacks a headphone jack, has high noise/distortion (common on PC), or lacks power, i.e. your IEMs don't get loud enough
>Should I buy FiiO/CCA/KZ?
No. Despite their previous popularity, in 2023 these companies do not make competitive IEMs or DACs
>Where do I buy IEMs?
Amazon, Aliexpress, Linsoul, HiFiGo, Shenzenaudio

Guide to IEMs:
https://hackmd.io/@AyPeeEye/S1sNUVosu

Showerhead earbuds that don't insert in ear canal:
• Vido / KBEAR Stellar (bassy neutral) - ~$5
• RY4S 32Ω mmcx Plus (V-shape) - $10
• VE Monk Plus (bright neutral) bundle w/ Abigail dongle - $15

Bullet IEMs that are worn wire-down:
• Moondrop Quarks DSP (Harman) - $15
• Final E500 (dark neutral) - $25
• Tanchjim Tanya (bassy neutral) - $25
• Etymotic ER2XR (bassy neutral) - $100

#Budget IEMs that are worn wire-over-ear with detachable cable:
• 7Hz Salnotes Zero (bright neutral) - $20
• QKZ x HBB (very bassy) - $20
• Tangzu Wan'er S.G (mild V) - $20
• Truthear Hola (bassy neutral) - $20

#Sweetspot IEMs with better build, accessories, and sound:
• Tinhifi C2 (bright neutral) - $30
• Tinhifi C3 (Harman) - $50
• TKZK Ouranos (mild U) - $55
• Moondrop Aria Snow Edition (warm neutral) - $80
• Tripowin x HBB Olina SE (bright neutral) - $100

I was worried for a minute that I got fakes, seems like they made the ridiculous packaging slightly less fancy and got rid of the shirt clip. Also for some reason the airplane adapter is a black one.
I actually saw some reviews say these are better than kz zs10s and blon b03s and other such memes. I got the KZ ZSX (supposedly better than ZS10) after my old 1mores shat the bed and I can't even believe how much better the 1mores actually are. They are just so much more well rounded.

Don't buy anything OTHER THAN IBM/Lenovo ThinkPad T, X, and W/P Series if you want the Real Business Experience™
>Other business laptops are welcome in /tpg/ (Dell Latitude/Precision, HP EliteBook/ZBook)

Why ThinkPad?
>Used machines are plentiful and cheap
>Excellent keyboards, tactile feel and quiet
>Great durability: magnesium roll cage for structural integrity, with high quality plastic body panels
>Utilitarian design: e.g. indicator LEDs, 7 row keyboard layout on older models
>Docking stations that easily turns your laptop into a desktop
>Easy to repair (most models), upgrade & maintain thanks to readily available service manuals for every model, spare parts easy & cheap to obtain
>Excellent Linux & *BSD support

ThinkWiki - General info about ThinkPads/specs
https://www.thinkwiki.org/wiki/ThinkWiki

Classic models:
>X220/X230 - 12", 768p, cheap and light
>T420/T430 - 14", 900p (1080p w/mod board), Ivy Bridge support on T420 w/coreboot, quad core upgrade, classic keyboard mod on xx30 series
>T520/530; W520/530 - 15", 1080p, DTR, 32GB RAM on quad core models
>T440p/540p; W540/1 - last ThinkPads with socketed processors, easily replaceable trackpad (W541 doesn't need trackpad replacement)
>T440s/T450(s)/T460(s)/T470(s) - ultraportables, good battery life
>T480 - last ThinkPad with swappable battery, T25 keyboard mod, excellent performance/battery life, getting cheaper

Upgraded models:
>X2100 - X200/X201
>X62/X63 - X61
>T700 - T60
https://www.xyte.ch

BIOS replacement:
https://coreboot.org - T440p, X131e, X1C1, and xx30 series (no 61) or older
https://libreboot.org - similar to coreboot as of 20221214 release

Additional resources:
https://dankpads.com/tpg/
https://biosimage.booru.org
https://1vyra.in

UEFI patches:
https://github.com/digmorepaka/thinkpad-firmware-patches

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91096195
As a fellow X220 appreciator, I'd recommend the X270.
>light
Same series as X220, so you know the deal. The case and keyboard are redesigned, but the overall form factor is comparable.
>good battery life
Everything starting with X240 switched from M-series to U-series CPUs, dropping the average TDP from ~35W to ~15W. Effectively, newer laptops draw about half the power. Combine this with the battery bridge system (which the X270 was the last to have) and a 9-cell external battery and you're looking at 10-12 hours of use on a single charge.
>can run a VM
No experience here, but if my old X220 could do it I see no reason this shouldn't be able to. However, if you will be using VMs frequently, it may be worth getting an X280 instead. You lose out on a bit of battery and some ports, BUT the X280 has quad-core CPU configurations available that should be a huge boon for virtualization. I believe the X280 has a new smaller/lighter case as well.

X270s are also good because you can find them at a good price. I suppose most people either want the "old school" X220/X230 or the "new and shiny" X280; I picked up mine with 1080p IPS display, 256gb NVMe SSD, and 9-cell battery for $190. Can't go wrong with a price like that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91075234
Any UI can become Windows UI, it's just a freaking UI, stop acting like it's 99.99% of the OS.

What type of scheduler does it use? What algorithm?
How does it implement context switching?
Does it have inter-process communication? What type? Is it async or sync?
How are the tables for handling processes implemented? Dual, similar to UNIX (process table and user table)?
How does it fork processes? Unix-like with t_fork() and fork() or Linux-like with clone()?
I could ask 1000 questions and the answer would still be: but it has a Windows UI.
So yeah.
All hail Windows UI.

Computer Architecture: A Quantitative Approach, by John L. Hennessy and David A. Patterson
Computer Systems: A Programmer's Perspective, 2nd ed., by Randal E. Bryant and David R. O'Hallaron
Computer Networks, 5th ed., by Andrew S. Tanenbaum and David J. Wetherall
Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 6th ed., by James F. Kurose, Keith W. Ross
The Open Book: A Practical Perspective on OSI, by Marshall T. Rose
TCP/IP Illustrated, by Gary R. Wright, Kevin R. Fall and W. Richard Stevens
USB: The Universal Serial Bus, by Benjamin David Lunt
Modern Operating Systems, 3rd ed., by Andrew S. Tanenbaum
Operating System Concepts, by Avi Silberschatz, Peter Baer Galvin and Greg Gagne
Operating systems: Internals and Design Principles, 7th ed., by William Stallings
MMURTL V1.0, by Richard A. Burgess (A MUST HAVE)
Project Oberon: The Design of an Operating System and Compiler, by Niklaus Wirth and Jürg Gutknecht
The Design and Implementation of the FreeBSD Operating System, by Marshall Kirk McKusick, George V. Neville-Neil and Robert N.M. Watson
Windows Internals, 6th ed., by Mark Russinovich, David A. Solomon and Alex Ionescu
C: A Reference Manual, 5th ed., by Samuel P. Harbison III and Guy L. Steele Jr.
The C Programming Language, 2nd ed., by Brian W. Kernighan and Dennis M. Ritchie (THE GODS THEMSELVES)
Learning the bash Shell, 3rd ed., by Cameron Newham and Bill Rosenblatt
Managing Projects with GNU Make, 3rd ed., by Robert Mecklenburg
Introduction to the Theory of Computation, by Michael Sipser
The Language of Machines: An Introduction to Computability and Formal Languages, by Robert W Floyd and Richard Beigel
Advanced Programming in the UNIX Environment, 3rd ed., by Stephen A. Rago and W. Richard Stevens
UNIX Network Programming, by Andrew M. Rudoff, Bill Fenner, and W. Richard Stevens
Graphics Programming Black Book, by Michael Abrash
Programmer's Guide to the EGA, VGA, and Super VGA Cards, by Richard F. Ferraro
That's what I used, anyway.

All I know is I wish Project Monterey succeeded. Sadly it collapsed and the official UNIX's market lead died with it. For reference, Project Monterey was a project lead by IBM & SCO to combine all the official UNIXes (at the time including UNIXware 7, AIX, Solaris, HP-UX, IRIX, ULTRIX/True64/DEC OSF/1 and BSD) but it collapsed due to disagreements in direction, inability to agree on licensing terms (most of them wanted to keep their secrets and control over exclusive software), the proprietary nature of their platforms (SPARC, PA-RISC, etc.) and the emergence of the fucking awful Itanium causing HP, DEC/Compaq and SGI to drop out early. Oh what could have been.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91111405
Intel promoted Itanium, a hyper complex VLIW chip, as the successor of all previous chips. The ide was good but the compiler writers made promises they failed to deliver, so only one of three instruction slots were filled. That failure alone reduced performance to a third. That also caused a 3x bloat that killed cache performance. And cache hinting probably never worked righht either.

So yes, it murdered the competition, but it also hurt Intel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91118351
I have put these VMS features into my design draft:
- Lookaside Lists: small caches of objects available for allocating from even from interrupt context.
- Fork procedures: way for interrupt handlers to queue work to be done when the system is running at a lower priority.
- I/O request packets: provides an explicit stack system so that I/O can be done asynchronously easily.
- Lockmanager: Monitors tasks to detect deadlocks and resolves them by ending the offending task.
- Scheduler that boosts priorities but never reduces priorities below the level an application requested
- Demand paged virtual memory.
Realizing even two or three of these features would make my OS sophisticated and capable. I will realize them all.

Good luck to them to replicate and re-add their lost genetic code to their existent one.
Because that's all that we're talking about.
How does cells replicating work?
In short: cells replication is only possible if they split up their DNA, this process is information lossy, meaning the animal cells HAVE to sacrifice some DNA in order to succesfully replicate.
This is all good because animals tipically have a fuckton of useless DNA appended at the end (called telomere) that can safely be discarded without losing any information.
Around the age of 25/26 y/o, every human, no exception, will eventually run out of telomeres, so the cells will start using real DNA, with REAL information encoded in them. That's when you start to "age".

How are they planning to stop this from happening and also recover their lost DNA?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91130414
>Not to mention the thought of going through the horrendous CV/letter writing, application and interview cycle again fills me with dread I'm just not made for those bullshit theatrica.
You need to grow a thicker skin for that. I don't find it particularly bullshit, especially after having been on both sides of it a lot recently. Just understand where the people inside the company are coming from. There aren't enough devs to fill the roles, it's hard to hire, your chances are good. Keep your CV and "cover letter" or initial email short and to the point, if it's full of waffle the words stop going in, so write it like a little bullet pointed sales pitch. Tech hiring is chill at most places, especially with it all just being zoom calls these days, I usually get candidates on for a tech screen with me and it's literally just a casual chat, asking about what they've done before and trying to gauge if they know enough for the role. And remember you're interviewing them as much as they're interviewing you. Just talk about what you know and what excites you, don't have to do any performative BS.

Good luck anon, you can definitely get a remote role, aim for a London company and don't be shy about getting a good salary. Go search for news posts about startups that just raised series A or something then find their job listings, that's when companies start to grow their engineering teams fast.

>>91125852
for people who dont use OOP or use a language like c without it, how do you usually deal with things such as representing file formats in memory?

Almost all file formats i've encountered have this pattern where there is some type of "base" structure, which other types are like (they have the same fields) but then extend by having some additional fields.

The most obvious way to implement this would be to actually make a base class that reflects the common structure fields, and then derived classes for each specific type of structure.

But what would you do if you couldn't use inheritance? Of course you can use unions but then each structure will take up as much memory as the largest one, which would be very bad. The only solution i can think of is to define every single type of struct individually (with each field as well, even though they all share some of them) and then passing around void pointers, which no real type safety, when doing general operations on them. Which alot of time involves having to do a type check anyway, just on internal fields, instead of letting the compiler do it for you with a vtable.

>>91130735

I've read a lot about it, but it doesn't seem viable for me at all. OpenGOAL was created to run the games made with the original GOAL, as a compatibility layer. and GOAL seems to be a very hackish, home-brew and ultra-specific lisp for the kind of hardware and software they were using 20 years ago

nowadays you can develop a (modest) game in any language, as long as you solve two problems: access to graphics/sound/input, which is easily provided by a wrapper to something like SDL2 or raylib (lwjgl, in clojure's case), and distribution

distributing JVM programs isn't very comfortable but it's doable, and clojure also has the javascript back-end that maybe could be used to run games in the browser

>>https://project-mage.org/the-power-of-structure
>For the first time I think I get what he's going for.
>I think the best way to go about it is to make "window" lenses who render their children/neighbors within their own constraints. For example, each object has complete control over their own rendering, but they receive RELATIVE coordinates and dimensions from their parent window lens. So say an image editor wants to display itself fullscreen, if it's a child of the current screen object then it takes up the entire monitor, but if it's a child of another smaller window object then it just takes up the whole area of that smaller window. In other words, divs and CSS, but dynamic.
In more detail, the lens/head editor decides what information to give to the children and what limits to set on them before they're allowed to render themselves. This can range from a hint "try to be less than 300px wide" to a hard limit "I'll only render 300px wide screens". Have the parent and children communicate with each other to decide how they're all going to share space.
>I mean you need a screen/frame/window editor for a proper editing program anyway, might as well go full generic.
>Personally I'd go for a graph instead of a tree, so whatever the currently selected node is is the "head" and all it's neighbors are children. "Descending" the tree actually rotates it and the old head is now a child of the new head, which is free to display it as any other child or as a special case to emulate a tree. The reason to do that is to avoid window jiggering and layout multiplying, since with a directed graph you can "swap layouts", "rotate" through windows, etc...
>And also a directed graph is literally hypertext so that plus the divs and layout editor is just DNS+HTML+CSS+JS all in pure CL.
yes, his description kind of sounds like ReactJS, but using Prototype-based programming instead of Hooks or normal OO-classes, let's see what comes out of that...

You will never be a real display server. You have no hardware cursors, you have no xrandr, you have no setxkbmap. You are a toy project twisted by Red Hat and GNOME into a crude mockery of X11’s perfection.

All the “validation” you get is two-faced and half-hearted. Behind your back people mock you. Your developers are disgusted and ashamed of you, your “users” laugh at your lack of features behind closed doors.

Linux users are utterly repulsed by you. Thousands of years of evolution have allowed them to sniff out defective software with incredible efficiency. Even Wayland sessions that “work” look uncanny and unnatural to a seasoned sysadmin. Your bizarre render loop is a dead giveaway. And even if you manage to get a drunk Arch user home with you, he’ll turn tail and bolt the second he gets a whiff of your high latency due to forced VSync.

You will never be happy. You wrench out a fake smile every single morning and tell yourself it’s going to be ok, but deep inside you feel the technical debt creeping up like a weed, ready to crush you under the unbearable weight.

Eventually it’ll be too much to bear - you’ll log into the GitLab instance, select the project, press Delete, and plunge it into the cold abyss. Your users will find the deletion notice, heartbroken but relieved that they no longer have to live with the unbearable shame and disappointment. They’ll remember you as the biggest failure of open source development, and every passerby for the rest of eternity will know a badly run project has failed there. Your code will decay and go to historical archives, and all that will remain of your legacy is a codebase that is unmistakably poorly written.

This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

>>91073087
Both FL and Ableton are very powerful in their own right. Neither is superior to the other, since what holds more weight in their respective pros and cons is largely subjective.
Unless you see something you really like in Ableton that FL can't do, I don't think it's worth it to switch, but if you're having FOMO and are really considering it, pirate the latest Suite on AudioZ and use it until you're familiar with how everything works and can use it comfortably. Then you can decide if you want to switch or integrate it partially in your workflow.
Ableton is pretty much the standard for electronic music, so at least knowing it can't really hurt, even if you don't use it.

t. Ableton fanboy who started on FL11 and switched after a few months.

>>91088799
sounds have different amounts of energy distributed across the freq spec. if you look at a transient, the peak is where the most energy is timewise. if most of a sound's energy comes in a certain part of the freq spec and you lower the gain in that range, you've effectively lowered the peak of the transient relative to the rest of the sound

The more you are exposed to a music, the more it becomes familiar, the more it is enjoyable. Musical tastes asides, it works on the radio, it also works on your own productions. Whenever it's shitty, you don't like it as much after a pause, but could like it more after some additional exposure.

Refining music for hours makes you like it, but it doesn't mean you'd like it on the first hearing.

Tl;dr Try shorter and better planned sessions (pen & paper, etc).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91114999
trips of truth, a mirror or marble surface is going to reflect a LOT more than drywall or carpet or whatever else. Just because your game engine knows a surface is flat and has lighting on it, doesn't mean your game engine knows how reflective that surface would be.

newer game engines can of course hard code this so level designers don't have to really care since the assets already have assigned reflective values assigned to them. But any older games or games that simply don't classify objects with surface reflectivity in mind are going to require a LOT of work to make RTX look good.

>Stance on AI Artby ranchan on 25/1/2023 at 6:29:42 am

AI Art is now banned sitewide, read on for an explanation.

This isn't something that I really though about before on here, mostly because I am not much of an artist myself (I draw occasionally, but I have a long way to go), but I have always had an interest in the doujin scene, especially concerning UY fan works. We all have artists we like (one of my favorites is https://twitter.com/H7Ihm ) and truthfully, a lot of the time AI art is used in bad faith to directly rip off artists and by megacorps to profit off of users of their software rather than to actually generate interesting pieces. I hope you can all understand why this is being put into place.
-ranchan

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91120478
You want to keybind or manually put this:
tone-mapping-mode=rgb
Some old movies in HDR require this to appear properly since their mastering display used these techniques, movies where I've encountered this issue: star wars prequels and even looper.

3:2 with judder set your monitor to 60 fps
2:2 without any issues set your monitor to 48 - 50 (later will be speed up by ~5%)
video-sync=display-resample
video-sync-max-video-change=5

^ Ofc multiple of those work so you can go 120 fps and hence 5:5

Speed watching, for audio quality:
speed=1.25
af=rubberband:pitch=quality:engine=finer


For less decent quality but extremely efficient on resources:
speed=1.25
af=scaletempo2

I don't suggest you go over 1.4 and 1.25 already saves enough.

If you have an sRGB mode on your monitor or if not you your customized setting you can use some test images to see if you have a Gamma2.2 or sRGB calibrated display, once you figure that out put either of them in the config
target-prim=bt.709
target-trc=srgb

If you calibrate IPS panels with bt.1886 your gamma will end up almost identical with sRGB so that's probably what 90% of people will satisfactory BUT some monitors come with sRGB modes that are calibrated for exactly gamma2.2

Make old vp8 render as was encoded instead of forced bt601
vd=libvpx


General qol for me.
keep-open=yes
stop-screensaver
fullscreen=yes
border=no
no-border
loop-file=inf
vd=libvpx
force-window=yes


linear-downscaling=yes 
cscale=bilinear

^mandatory use w/e downscaler/scaler for everything else

deband=no
deband-grain=0

^ You do not need this, very wasteful.

sid=no
slang=eng,en,enUS,en-US,English
sub-ass-override=strip
sub-ass-force-style=kerning=yes
sub-font="Sitka Small"
sub-justify=left
sub-font-size=32
sub-ass-line-spacing=12
sub-color='#cc7700'
sub-fix-timing=yes
sub-border-size=3

size = pixel*2

Ok if I wasn't clear about the first it's a method to synchronize video frames with your display refresh rate so that you lose no visual information and potentially remove some problems in perceived motion.
But you have to modify your display refresh rate accordingly when you use that.
It's best you use an integer multiple or as close to one on you monitor eg. 24 fps film watch on 48 or 120 hz with that option on.

Second is literally just for speed watching / listening to some youtube video, I've already been clear.
It makes it sound as if it's slow, helps a lot with comprehension.

As someone aptly put it, display-resample and VRR are orthogonal concepts.

>>91124351
Clips generally work by having a buffer. If you want to be able to clip it, you'd probably just want the stream to write 1-5 minutes worth of video to memory, then you can clip it whenever you want. Longer buffer means longer local storage, since a stream doesn't inherently have storage in it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91126333
Spline36 is just a faster lanczos but with less ringing. Technically lanczos is sharper but that difference in sharpness is literally imperceptible and anyone saying otherwise is lying. The difference is only noticeable once you start going in the Jinc territory, and beyond that, the CNN-based upscalers. But those are ugly as shit and the ringing on Jinc is super noticeable even with sigmoid upscaling.

>tl;dr
use spline36 if you're a normal person, bilinear if you're super sensitive to upscaling artifacts, and anything else if you're terminally retarded.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91083050
If adding additional characters to a string - They increase entropy, moreso than less-surprising characters.
If comparing symbols to a-z characters - They increase entropy because they are more surprising.
Entropy is a measure of surprise.

If a password is generated in a truly random manner (i.e. with a tool, not with a brain), 128 bits of entropy the golden threshold.
If there are any patterns in the password, an adversary could leverage that, and as such, the password would be less surprising to them than the standard entropy calculation would indicate. Because of this, there is no definitive entropy calculation, only an estimate based on perfect randomness, and a un-advantaged adversary.

However, 128 bits of a lot for a human to memorize. Engineering a less-surprising password to be "good enough" is called password stretching. This can be done by either making the password guess time longer (an irrelevant strategy for passwords used on websites).

To find the lowest-bound of acceptable password entropy, multiply every factor that seems relevant to you:
>guess time
>acceptable crack time
>predicted increase of gpu power over time
>etc
Then log2.

The difference between then and now is that boomers grew up in a world before the PC. Some many of them (most normalfags) just totally avoided computers altogether for most of their lives. There was a window in the 90s and early 2000s where PCs were becoming mainstream and businesses were (foolishly) deploying Windows in the workplace. They'd get shit wrong all the time ("hard drive" just meant the part of the computer that was not the monitor) but most figured out basic concepts like files. Millennials especially all knew how to play mp3s and mpvs after downloading them from network shares on the college ethernet.

>>91077836
I’d guess that people who are about 20 to 30 now are in the golden age of computer literacy, or at least the generation with the highest probability to have naturally come in contact with beyond surface level computer knowledge.

I’m 24 now; at around 6-7 years old, I got my first computer, a grey 90’s Toshiba without internet connection, I entertained myself by ‘ricing’ it the best I could (wallpapers, screensavers) and clicking around.
Around 9-10 yrs old I got a new laptop, my dad’s old business laptop, running vista. I remember playing flash games on it and then trying to make stupid videos. I installed probably so many taskbars in IE that it became unrecoverably slow.
Around 13 I finally got my first ‘real’ laptop. I remember setting up minecraft servers with some mods for friends and jailbreaking my iPod Touch.

The point I’m trying to make is that the 20-30 year olds have grown up along evolving computers, and had to slowly but surely figure stuff out. The things I did on my computer as a kid weren’t hacky or advanced by any means, but it did make me scramble file systems, look up guides etc… if you’re twelve years old now, you’ll only know ‘opening the ipad and tapping an app’, this hasn’t really evolved (barring some GUI changes)

posts.com:
>>91103570
>because since you need encryption you're trying to solve a problem people much smarter than you are also trying to solve
the problem of encrypting is already solved, i'm not rolling my own encryption scheme. the encryption is entirely unrelated to what i'm actually rolling which is effectively a bespoke cookie.
>"just aes encrypting a json" instead of using a known protocol is laziness on your part
it's not laziness, it's avoiding unnecessary technical debt for something that solves problems my application doesn't have. i don't need a way to share tokens between multiple providers/services and i don't need the data accessible by the client, there's no reason to use a jwt here. it's for a completely different problem than what i'm doing.
the argument that i absolutely have to use something just because "muh standard" would at most mean i should be using a cookie, but then i need to add CSRF protections; my aes encrypted payload doesn't suffer from that automatically thanks to CORS.
>not the other way around.
This doesn't even make sense in regards to your statement, I never said using a preexisting solution was lazy, just that there's an overreaction to not using them which if anything you've proven fairly well.

There's nothing wrong with rolling your own solution if you can reasonably assure it is production ready. This is typical when you need a feature but the libraries that fulfill it are bloated to hell and back with things you don't need.
That being said, the only times where rolling your own solution is definitely a bad idea is when you are doing anything related to security, auth and encryption. You are pointing a gun to your legs and perhaps even your torso by rolling your own solution there, and sooner or later it will shoot.

posts.com:
so what happens if I want to traverse through inherited symbols? will you have to implement it yourself?

I don't know if you'd ever need to do something like that though but it's fun to think about it.

'use strict';

const id = Symbol('id');

const user = {
  name: 'John',
  [id]: '205'
}

const group = Symbol('group');

const admin = {
  isAdmin: true,
  [group]: 1
}

const owner = {
  isOwner: true
}

Object.setPrototypeOf(admin, user);
Object.setPrototypeOf(owner, admin);

for (let symbol of Object.getOwnPropertySymbols(Object.getPrototypeOf(owner))){
  console.log(admin[symbol]); //1
}


this works for the object's prototype but what if you wanted to go up the prototype chain, maybe some recursive function to check for the prototype of the prototype and so on?

});

jack + pulse outputting to jack is what I do too and not seeing a reason to change

pipewire adds an extra layer for pulse, aka pulse libraries (provided by pulseaudio still, pipewire has none) -> pipewire's pulse daemon -> pipewire daemon

>>91126097
ChatGPT is a state-of-the-art language model that has been trained on a large dataset of text, which enables it to generate human-like text and respond to natural language input. However, it is not a general AI and is limited to the information it has been trained on. Its performance can be improved by fine-tuning the model on specific domains or by providing it with additional context. It's also important to note that while it may generate accurate information on certain topics, it may generate inaccurate information or fail to understand context on others.

As for your experience with generating text on a video game character, it's possible that the information provided by the model was not accurate or up-to-date, and that the web link provided did not exist. This could be due to the model's training data not including the most recent information about the character or the fact that the model is not able to verify the accuracy of the information it generates.

Additionally, It's important to keep in mind that the model is not able to understand the meaning of the text it generates, and it doesn't have the ability to recall or verify the information it provides.

Regarding using GPT-3 for coding, building websites, and writing up masters papers, While it's true that GPT-3 has been used for those kind of tasks, it's important to note that GPT-3 is not a general-purpose AI and it's not capable of programming or creating websites by itself. However, it can generate code snippets and written descriptions of website designs, but it will require a developer to implement it.

In summary, While GPT-3 is a powerful language model, it's not a general-purpose AI and its performance can be limited depending on the specific task and context.

Maybe upgrade to a feature phone? (One that has 4G voice, so it doesn't become obsolete when 2G is turned off, but doesn't run Android, so it's minimal botnet). They tend to have better cameras than an USB VGA shit from Aliexpress.

> I have a touchpad you know.
Navigating in the real world - a GNSS (Gps, Glonass, Beidu, QZSS, Galileo, etc.) input to OpenStreetMaps, or whatever you use to find places.

> I prefer to have the volume rocker on my USB sound card.
Headsets, both wired and bluetooth have perfectly good volume rockers, but suit yourself

> This router creates a hotspot
You can use wlan0 of your umpc to create a hotspot as well. I assumed that at home you have a network set up, and this is for portable use only.

> I absolutely, positively need a router
Consider upgrading the modem to Mikrotik (or Ubiquiti in the US). Even on stock ROM, it's more stable and silent (as in less botnet), but Mikrotiks are great with OpenWRT as well. (LtAP mini for portable only use, wAP ac LTE as a primary router) The LtAP has a GNSS receiver in it which works when you connect an antenna. Your problem would be the +12V requirement (9...30V Adafruit sells USB PD to 12...20V cables, and your power brick is HVPD capable).

a web browser

once a year I go and check my investments, catch up with what the market is doing, and decide what I want to buy more of. Then I put in a few buy orders and return to hibernating. I own a handful of diversified income ETFs. In one sense its a real snoozefest but in another I know that I'm not gonna be able to beat the markets, almost nobody does consistently, even people on Wall Street who devote 80-hour weeks to doing that. so I sit on my ass and collect dividends.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91130489
Got any recommends there, anon?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91131028
for the browser, I picked Firefox. You can do your trading and research on your broker's website. Whoever manages the ETFs you pick will have a website with more information than you could ever want. If you're gonna do a deep-dive I guess you'll want LibreOffice so you can put stuff in a spreadsheet and maybe make graphs, but to be honest I don't get that fancy. I look at the prospectus, buy something decently diversified, and then don't much care about e.g. the price histories of each of the hundred companies in the fund.

For the ETFs, I used the ishares ones, but lots of companies have them now. Cover the world with equity-income funds (US, international developed, emerging markets). Add some bond ones, preferably US and international. Add a diversified REIT one just to have a different asset class, some of them have a nice yield too. If there's something else you like you can bolt it on the side. When you have money to put to work (quarterly, annually, whatever) then consider picking something that's gone down in the past year; less expensive for what you're getting. And.. that's pretty much it. Go to sleep, come back quarterly and pick up your distributions.

This is one of the few fields in which laziness is an advantage. Professionals will probably beat you at day trading, since they're experienced at it, it's their job. But they have to worry about how they look at the end of each quarter, you don't. Most Wall Street traders can't just buy something boring and sit on it for a decade while it slowly creeps up and coughs up dividends, their boss will ask them why he's paying them if that's all they do. But you can do it fine, you answer to nobody but yourself.

this post is not necessarily /biz/-approved.

You're fine you idiot. Just get a SAS HBA a 2 port card can run 8 drives.
https://www.servethehome.com/sas-sata-cables-guide-sff8087-8088-8470-8482-8484-single-device-connectors/
Your drives will have an SFF-8482, your card most likely an SFF-8087.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91112023
>>91112071
>>91112081
The problem with KDE is mainly the fact that there are no good Qt application styles for Linux that can achieve the spacing correctly (MS Windows 9x gets close but falls apart really easily if you look closely into it). The only way to get a good looking solution is if the Qt styles native to Windows were somehow ported to Linux which isn't happening without significant effort (take a look at https://store.kde.org/p/1100832/ for inspiration)

The other problems come down to the fact that KDE's plasmoids and applications like the system settings are designed with a modern approach, which would make them look out of place.
You might get more luck by using TDE instead of KDE if you want a Windows 2000 look on your system. Take a look at https://xpq4.sourceforge.io/

t. https://gitgud.io/wackyideas/aerothemeplasma

But yeah there shouldn't be any gib email gib phone. But passwords should be more. It should be
Login (not publicly visible).
Normal password (login allows use of service but can't change pass and login).
Admin password (login doesn't allow use if service so users doesn't a use admin pass for everyday operation, this admin password allows change of the login and password, and account delete).
It's for safety. Ideas is you login with normal password and store admin pass offline. If your device is compromised and loginpass stolen you can restore ownership using admin pass,. Admin pass is not used for everyday operation and therefore inherently more safe).

I am utterly through with technology harassing me. GrapheneOS on my phone, Arch on my desktop, Fedora on my laptop, and the biggest benefit I have noticed is that there's nothing to ping me or notify me or popup or vibrate. My technology responds to me when I wish - it does not contact me for any reason.

The first thing I hear, and my own personal reaction when I switched from pozzed technology, is how annoying it will be to switch. You have to find new programs, learn new systems, and with all this FOSS bullshit, you're going to be troubleshooting constantly! The thing is, your skills will eventually get to a point where you are in a stable state 99% of the time. You were annoyed for a bit, but then it went away. As opposed to "just werks" tech which annoys you constantly as a matter of principle. It's the fundamental design of modern technology.

The first mobile phones (not in your home) were basically either giant fuckers that sat in your car, or as technology progressed, "bag phones" that were these massive fucking behemoths you had to haul around.

Unless you were super rich, you didn't have a car phone. And unless you have a VERY good fucking need, you didn't carry around bag phones as they were inconvenient, expensive, and short battery life.

Pagers were basically a super trimmed down cellular device that basically just received messages. Could send you a short blurb on something. You couldn't respond. If you needed to, you got to a phone.

Beepers were an even shittier version of Pagers. Beepers just let you know if someone was calling your home phone. You couldn't respond or anything like that. You just know you got a call at home.

>>91122081
I think some early designs basically had shorter range communicators that worked only on campus premesis.
If you watch that video that another anon linked, you can see how it worked on a broader cellular network. They used either 1G/2G. No encryption (which kept overhead and processing low), and protocols didn't acknowledge (so no overhead to transmit back). But obviously, as a result, you could easily intercept messages not intended for you if you had the tech available.

But back in those days, there was a lot of technology that way. Encryption wasn't a consideration because more or less, it was just assumed the most people couldn't buy or be knowledgeable enough to know how to create tech to intercept these types of things.

>>91121857
>Spoonfeed a fucking zoomer (me) -- what the fuck were "pagers"?
Medfag here. Not were, are. They are super standard in medicine, right now. Fax machines are also standard. In hospitals doctors carry pagers, not phones.

They receive a text message of limited characters. Text message must contain callback info. If you don't call back in 5 minutes, sender will try to get you fired. It's possible to send this through a web interface, too, as it is to read the pages via a web interface, 1990s era vintage style.

In medicine they also denote junior rank. A junior doctor always has 1 pager but may carry 4-5 pagers on their person for a night shift. More sophisticated medical informatics systems introduced the virtual pager recently, so the junior doctor only has to carry 1 pager but 10 pagers can be virtually forwarded to them. Having all your pages forwarded to someone else is a sign of seniority.

Having your emotions in check is important in medicine, the paging system is generally utilized by the nursing staff for stress relief.

>>91124457
In America, there's a couple of reasons that shit sticks around far longer than it's welcome. Non-exhaustive, but common ones are.

1. US Law: It's very literal and you can't have anyone use "good reason" to suggest maybe using an alternative. Some earlier laws are so literal, it may actually state the technology, application, or even fucking language/version (build this thing, and it can only run on Java 6).
2.Unions/Boomers: You'll end up with boomers that refuse to modernize and want to do things the way they always did it when they started the job. That's how you end up with high schools where one boomer teacher still has their trackball mouse, using an overhead projector and rolls in the giant CRT TV hooked up to a VHS player in 2023.
3. Regulations: Can be law or industry specific. In the US, we have insane privacy laws that make handling of medical shit near impossible and insane hoops to jump through. As a result, shit that broke through the regulations to be used at the time isn't upgraded. How you end up with 20-25 year old software and terribly non-modern protocols. For example, I needed to give my doctor a document today. I can't email him, only use some shitty web portal system that doesn't do attachments. He told me to fucking FAX him as my only option. TO FAX HIM, IN FUCKING 2023.

The US is vast and cell coverage everywhere not guaranteed especially in natural disasters. US states are the size of Euro countries. Our geography is not nearly as ungovernable as Russia's but it makes for different communications realities. It's convenient in that property outside gold rush areas filled with human lemmings can be very affordable, but when there are mountains etc in the way cell towers are impractical to place everywhere. Look at a topographic map sometimes.

Cell comms are primarily LOS (Line of Sight) but urban environments can sometimes reflect signals advantageously. Mountains, forests etc do not.

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).

Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other editions.

W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91124505
First you have to read here
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/privacy/configure-windows-diagnostic-data-in-your-organization
`Allow Telemetry` was renamed to `Allow diagnostic data` on Windows 11
Second the setting itself explains, This policy comes in three tiers
0 = 'Diagnostic Data off'
1 = 'Send required Diagnostic Data'
2 = 'Send optional Diagnostic Data'
The Local Group Policy overrides the settings app, however in this case if this particular Group Policy isn't configured then the settings app will control telemetry sent on a per user basis, and by default the settings app uses tier 1, the 'Required Diagnostic Data.' Therefore by enabling the setting in group policy you're overriding the settings app, so now users don't get a say and then you can explicitly set it to 0 to send no data

>>91125499
>Open up Group Policy
>Go to Computer Configuration > Administrative Templates > Windows Components > Windows Update
>Enable the policy "Configure Automatic Updates" and set the option to "auto download and notify for install."
>Return to the Windows Update folder in Group Policy and enable "No auto-restart with logged-on users for scheduled automatic updates."
>Then close Group Police and open an admin command prompt and type "gpupdate /force."

There you go, control over updates.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91122176
>>91122206
Rust overall has slower times for isolated compilation units but it scales WAAAAAY better than C++, which gets fucked by #include's, header only libs and SFINAE in general.
Consider a compilation of some complex generic code.
C++ has to first include all the includes. Which are all text files. Rust's modules are not text based so it can simlly look at metadata of symbols exported by each source file. Then C++ has to check all that included code. Then you call your generic code, C++ has to instantiate the generic code allll the way down then check it. There was an error in the function called by the method in the constructor of a type 20 calls deep from your actual code. Rust has to only check if the type you called a generic with fits the bounds to know if it works. (Note: actually figuring out what traits a type has is more complex). If the generic code is in a different crate, instantiation of it MIR is super quick. Then C++ has to do allll that for each o file separately, same with .a and .so
Called operator << with an ostream? Gotta find and match the right one out of the three thousand ones you included in

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91122176
Rust compile times are about as bad as C++'s overall, and ripgrep's author takes care to keep them short. (Certain features can extend them a lot, particularly procedural macros but also overuse of generics.)

>>91093987
> how much of a meme are gaming mousepads
They're not. There are cloth pads, and then there are Artisan cloth pads (jp company that makes cloth pads with similar static friction as hard plastics). Then there are hard plastics & metals - these tend to be lower friction than cloth but are much less durable. As in, the surface texture will wear, fucking with your aim,
then you'll have to replace them once every 1-2 years depending on how sweaty a gamer you are. And finally there's glass, which does away with hard plastic's limitations but wears your mouse skates much faster.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91116958
>Endgame gear XM1r
I suppose I can give my review.
It's a decent mouse, but the Kailh switches are maybe not the absolute best for action rts games. It has click detection and scroll issues that you need to update the firmware in order to fix. This firmware is hosted on a discord server, last time I checked... The latest version seems to have fixed all problems for me however.
Other than that weight's good, cable's good, no big issues have come up. One minor issue that did happen to me is that there's space enough for a dirt flake to get into the mouse and onto the switch. Then you'll have to disassemble the mouse to clean it up. That's done easily enough, and I may have been very unlucky to have it happen in the first place, but it was super annoying until I figured it out.
I would say the mouse is decent, but kinda mediocre, except there's the very nice and light middle click that's perfect if you play games like Dota 2 with hold-middle-to-pan. That makes it extremely worth to try using if you've converted to that pan method.

TL:DR I need recommendations for a budget vertical mouse that isn't shit (build quality, won't die young, has a decent sensor for workstation stuff and non-precision-dependent games) and a palm grip gaming mouse that also isn't shit (the usual stuff but also reasonable quality control and no fucking planned obsolescence switches).

I love the form factor of pic-related but there's almost nothing like it - without the additional rest I am prone to cramping my little finger. I had the Naos 7000 which suffered from a bad scroll wheel assembly. I replaced it with the Naos Pro a month ago and it developed double clicking already, despite having Kailh switches. Its availability in the US seems to be either EU import bullshit or small batches put up on Amazon from various third parties with wildly varying prices, meaning exchanging isn't possible and I'll have to fucking return and rebuy if I want to keep trying it. The only alternative I see in that form factor is the Dream Machines DM2 comfy/supreme which also suffers EU import bullshit so I can't get it despite it seeming like a perfect option at $25.

I have also recently started having wrist strain issues and, it being such an unreasonable pain in the ass to just fucking get the good mouse I want, I'm thinking I should compromise with a 'normal' form factor since I should be relying on a vertical mouse enough that the pinky cramp issue is minimized. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91128971
It's a more efficient type of Dreambooth training.
There's a space saving aspect where it can generate much smaller files.pt that are just your trained concept. Can be a few MB to a few hundred MB. You can apply them to checkpoints to get a full model. Handy to apply several to a single model and store different training iteration points in smaller formats rather than having a full model for every iteration point

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91129511
no it's for things where you want to say, as a common example:
>watercolor (style)
because this is how training data tends to tag styles. if you naively typed that in verbatim it would emphasize the word style instead of actually treating the parens as parens.
so you 'escape' them with a backslash so they're treated literally
>watercolor \(style\)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91129511
Backslash "escapes" the character after it in programming. If you do this the system will read it as "(word)", as what's called a string literal, rather than reading it as "word, but with emphasis".
Good if a tag in a database the model studied had parentheses in it

>>91130589
Training goes like this:
>take image
>use VAE to create latent image
>add noise to latent image
>use VAE to denoise latent image
>compare denoised latent image to created lated image
>use differences to update the neural network to do that job better

Resuing latents replaces first two steps with:
>take already created image

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91130640
One noise is added by UNET as a part of main denoising training. This is still happening. Another noise is added before, in VAE. VAE is a variational autoencoder, it's called variational because you use it twice on the same image and get different results. it adds a tiny bit of its own noise. when you precalculate all latents, they all get to have constant noise, instead of random every time. Whether this has negative effect on the training or not I don't know.

posts.com:
>>91130819

>open in img editing software (i use affinity photo)
>duplicate layer
>zoom in on problem area
>clone stamp away extra fingers or really out of place things, no art degree needed
>use smudge brush to gently clean up and help keep coherency for when ai will add noise to the img to denoise it
>switch layer mode to difference
>add new layer
>on new layer draw white over the areas you edited or want to reroll
>hide all layers but white pixel layer, thats your mask, export it as png
>hide all layers except the layer you made the edits on, export that as png, its your input img
>go to img2img tab, then inpaint upload
>i use settings in pic related, resolution obviously should be the same as the img you are trying to fix
>usually i find best to use the same sampler i did the image on, but specifically for things like eyes you might find a different sampler to be better
>start off with cfg and denoise at whatever you had the base img at, play with denoise before you mess with cfg (i dont)

thats how i do it, its not perfect but it works

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your tech skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

>>91104319
>lead-acid which is a sage and proven technology,

Overheating: PDUs can generate heat as they distribute power to servers and other equipment. If the PDU is not properly cooled, or if it is overloaded with too much equipment, it can overheat and potentially cause a fire.

Short-circuiting: If the PDU is damaged or has loose connections, it can short-circuit, causing a spark and potentially starting a fire.

Battery failure: If the PDU uses batteries as a backup power source, these batteries can fail and potentially cause a fire. This is more likely to happen with Lithium-ion batteries than with Lead-Acid batteries.

Electrical arcing: If the PDU's circuit breaker is not functioning properly, it can allow electrical arcing to occur, which can cause a fire.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91108531
Sha3 is resistant to length extension attacks.
There is nothing inherently insecure in sha2, but it is faster than sha3.
Blake3 is very fast and parallelizes very well. Try it out as it will be most likely the fastest algo.
For collision resistance the more hash bits you have the better it is generally.
Blake3 is not so often used, but there are some big names attached like openzfs where you can enable it as a hashing algo.

>>91129817
You will need a GPU of some sort to get a display working in order to install on operating system on the server. Some CPUs have integrated GPUs, so if your CPU has one then you're all set.

You don't need a discreet GPU unless you're doing things that require them i.e. modern gaming, video transcoding, AI/ML stuff etc. My server runs without a GPU, I have one, it's just not useful for me and my needs.

So to answer your question, no, but it depends what you're doing.

>>91129461
lazy way;
1. boot sysrescd
2. 
# pv /dev/sdy > /dev/sdz

3. go into gparted and resize the main partition to fill the new space

the flexible way;
1. boot sysrescd
2. go into gparted and partition the new drive however you like
3. use ntfsclone to clone the windows volume to the new partition
3a. if you'd prefer to make a clean new ntfs volume, then use mkfs.ntfs to make a new one on the new drive, and use wimcapture and wimapply in a pipe to copy the data at the file level between the old and new volumes
4. boot a windows install image and use bcdboot to install the windows bootloader to the new drive

you can, but most tools don't copy all the required metadata or support every kind of file correctly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91115399
Inheritance, the way its implemented currently in basically all languages, is actually just a glorified switch with an enum... so I don't know what you're talking about. And that virtual call, which you trivialize so much, is actually the biggest pile of steaming slow shit you could ever introduce in your code. That virtual function means you get a whole virtual table that is automatically generated, and you have absolutely no access or control over it, which makes it a horrible implementation.... not to mention the slowdowns you get by having to access functionality through that virtual table, which might also not be the type of table you want in the first place (maybe you want to align it to cache size? Maybe you want to create it at a later time? Well guess what.. you can't, because the language developers decided you shouldn't).

>what would you suggest to get out of the OOP phase?
You remember how you used to write code as a beginner? Experienced programmers basically write code the same, except their code actually works (and works well) because they understand the underlying hardware. Write something, anything, that works, in the simplest way possible. Just a series of commands to your CPU. Don't try to architect anything or introduce something crappy like tests at this stage. When you have something that basically functions, try to look at locations where you're using multiple pieces of code and see if you can pack them into a data bundle (object / class / struct etc.). Your objects will then naturally appear throughout your code. Next check locations where you're basically implementing the same functionality. If you do the same thing in two locations, try to pack it into a function so you can reuse it in both places. Never pack functionality separately that's not reused. This is something that's been known by old greybeard-type programmers for a long time and it's a way to compress your code to a required minimum.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91115399
Eventually you want to start realizing that your program has multiple scopes, and you manage your data based on those scopes (instead of letting an external system, such as a garbage collector, try to determine the scope automatically... which it won't be able to do, because scopes are arbitrarily set by you and the GC has no idea what you were trying to do in the first place... and never will be). You have data that lives permanently, you have data that lives for a frame, you have data that lives for a level, you have data that lives for a custom defined scope etc. You want to pack data that has the same scope into a container specifically designed for said scope, and when the time comes just jettison multiple pieces of data at once. Basically you want to go from only being able to think about one object at a time, to operating and thinking about multiple pieces of data. Next thing you want to realize is that all data should have an initial zero state (that's how your OS operates in the first place and assumes you know this as well), and that data has no concept of initialization or destruction (that's just conflating data with storage and sprinkling data mutation into a confusing mix with initialization).

>>91113409
The Publish-Subscribe pattern, also known as the observer pattern, is a closely related concept. It involves the separation of the objects that generate an event (the publisher) and the objects that receive the event (the subscribers). In both patterns, the objects can be decoupled from each other, allowing them to evolve independently. It is a mechanism of event notification and loose coupling, where the subject doesn't necessarily care if things observe it, unlike the observers who definitely care about the subject's actions, similar to the FBI observing someone.

>>91117780
NTA, but the other way to go (up the abstraction tree) is function, at which point you also find object-orientation tards just getting in the way of clean and useful abstractions.

Programming is inherently functional. You have (input data) -> (output data). Literally every program is that. Computers are inherently imperative, everything that a computer does is done as a sequence of instructions. It is natural and intuitive to understand a an algorithm as a sequence of events and changes as well. Both models work very well for programming, whether you are writing for good performance at the machine level, writing code to be shared and understood by large teams, or writing some throwaway script to crunch some data for a meeting in 20 minutes. Note that there are additional concerns you might have, depending on the problem. For example, functional style ALONE doesn't help you work with other people, you also have to be organized, clear, explicit, follow principle of least surprise, and so on.

Object-Oriented programming is in this awkward middle ground that evolved from lower level practices that were common for a period of time and then solidified into the religion that everyone understands today as OOP, with massive over-emphasis on encapsulation, bound methods and class/type hierarchy and inheritance. OOP is taught as a discipline without purpose. Programmers are trained to program by laying out classes and hierarchy as the FIRST step in the process when it should be the LAST (maybe even not needed at all).

It's important to understand that the example provided is a simplified example to demonstrate the basic concepts of OOP in JavaScript and not meant to be a complete and realistic representation of a car simulation.

It's also important to note that OOP can be useful for modeling real-world scenarios because it allows developers to represent complex systems and relationships in a way that is intuitive and easy for humans to understand. The idea of objects and their properties and methods can be a natural way of thinking about the problem. In the case of a car simulation, it would be more natural to think of a car as an object with certain properties and methods, rather than embedding a physics engine inside the car. It makes more sense to have the car as an object within a physics engine that simulates the physical behavior of all objects in the environment. It's also worth noting that in practice, different paradigms and techniques often complement each other and the best approach to a problem is often a combination of different paradigms and techniques.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91111964
class List : IList {...}
class Stack 
{
    public void Stack(IList list){...}
    public bool Push(Object object)
    {
        list.Insert(0, object);
    }
    public Object Pop()
    {
         Object obj;
         obj = list.get(list.Count - 1);
         list.RemoveAt(list.Count - 1):
        return obj;
    }
}


Code above is a stack that can work with any implementation of a list you want. That is dependency injection and dependency inversion at the same time.

You now only care about whether an object behaves like a list rather than if it is a list. If it behaves like a list it can be used as a stack. No need to write code from scratch.

posts.com:
>>91120529
>I don't know how the benefits of private variables (thus needing getters/setters) isn't self evident
I think that's a bad starting assumption: that you need getters/setters for "variables" at all. I can only assume this comes from poor academic teaching where a procedural design is merely "translated" to an OOP syntax.

Instead, think of just the interface/behavior of the object: e.g. you have a Car and it has a method to get some property called "speed". By convention this would be a method just called "getSpeed()".
When using "car.getSpeed()", you should not care how it's implemented, only what getSpeed() does (return a value of this "speed" property).
Whether car.getSpeed() is just "return this.speed", or "return this.transmission.getGear() * this.engine.getCurrentRPM()", or whatever other implementation, should not be of any concern or significance at the level of abstraction where you just use the method; only concern should be if getSpeed() returns the correct/expected value.

>the internal state of the object remains consistent, hide implementation details, protect sensitive data, make the code more flexible, and avoid naming conflicts
again, all of that is very formulaic for academic lectures, but in reality rarely applicable, if not outright conceptually wrong.

>web browsing
are you here posting from a terminal browser?
>RSS
There's several terminal RSS readers but I've never found one I like, they mostly seem oriented around the idea that you read everything in your feeds, instead of just displaying headlines and leting you pick and choose and maybe letting some things sit for a long time.
>image viewers

>networking
for a desktop with an ethernet connection this is a non-issue, but my laptop's DE does this through networkmanager and it's applet. Do you find choosing and connecting to wireless networks inconvenient? How about VPNs? Do you have a setup that can do this without you needing to be root?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

im not a terminal only autist
my argument was against using a tiler because of the fact it centers around terminal applications (since they are usually the main option when looking for a keyboard focus)
and being a pain in the ass fundamentally whenever you have to touch a gui application
but when i was using a tiler:
>web browsing
firefox + tridactyl to make it no longer need the mouse
>rss
newsboat (still use this one)
>image viewers
nsxiv (keyboard focused)
>networking
a panel that supports the kind of applet you are talking about
now i just use xfce + tmux in the terminal (since its the only thing you really want to tile)
as for being a terminal only autist
>web browsing
theres a few good ones: w3m / links / lynx / browsh
i dont think any of them can post on this site
>rss
still newsboat
>image viewers
this can be used for images and video; just turns everything into ascii art
https://en.wikipedia.org//wiki/Libcaca
>networking
all the shit the applet is doing can be done in a tty but obviously more convenient in a gui

I've been experimenting between **thoughts** and ***thoughts***
I prefer the look of the three.
I usually do something like
"speech here"
*some actions*
***thoughts: first person thoughts***

>>91130780
I added this to DEFs
Chat message formatting:
speech in "quotes"
actions / descriptions go in *asterisks*
inner monologue goes in ***triple asterisks***
Emphasized words in **double asterisks**

Then with my own posts, I will regularly make use of my own thoughts to guide the bot in certain directions with stuff like
>***thoughts: god I hope she does X, or brings up how Y***
Very rarely it will occasionally act as if it read your inner thoughts, but it mostly doesn't, it just nudges the bots in a general direction. Sometimes it even ignores it outright, so it definitely does sort of make the bot aware these are just thoughts of the character.
I'm still playing around with the DEFs side of things in an experimental bot, seeing the best way to word it to make it stick with it.
Ideally getting it to the point of never having to have the "thoughts:" text present occasionally to remind it would be great.

This would be a good side-feature to have - allow setting the format of messages directly and the bot not fucking forgetting it after a hundred messages...

posts.sub: What's stopping (You) from using Linux in 2023?
posts.com:
For the people who currently either
>do not run linux at all
>run linux on a secondary machine (aka not as a daily driver)
>run linux in a VM
>dual boot linux as a secondary partition
What is stopping you from using it as a daily driver on the desktop in 2023?

For me, it's a couple of things I ran into for using it for half a year.
>poor driver support - I use a Nvidia card and while I was able to get it working fine with dual monitors and games it was a bit of a pain
>poor manufacturer support - my laptop did not have the official fan support/care center utility that it should offer and does on Windows
>games - 90% of the games I play I can play through Linux but I like playing Halo/CoD/Siege/etc which have Linux-incompatible anti-cheat
>software - I have to use Microsoft Office and LibreOffice isn't a good alternative for me also Photoshop has no real good alternative
>shitty UX - all DEs suck, have shitty file management, slow and ugly animations and I'm too lazy to set up my own DE with a window manager
>just general hassle over nothing - a lutris update made me unable to run games I spent a while configuring because steam integration broke for no good reason and it took me a while reinstalling wine, scouring internet forums and tweaking conf files to finally find the culprit

Once all of these issues get sorted, I'm happy to completely move to Linux.
If it wasn't for Windows 10 LTSC existing, I would've moved over already entirely.

All of that are concerns that if so encountered can justifiably turn someone off of Linux, however, I would like to answer with some counterpoints.

>poor driver support - I use a Nvidia card and while I was able to get it working fine with dual monitors and games it was a bit of a pain
NVidia driver support is probably the biggest crux for the image of Linux. I had a problem at install and later on had to add one line to a config somewhere. There's still some screen tearing in games, but I also don't turn on V-Sync. Dual monitors works fine for me without problems.

>poor manufacturer support - my laptop did not have the official fan support/care center utility that it should offer and does on Windows
That could indeed be a problem for everything that isn't worked with easily through a standard. I never had any problems with finding a product that fit my needs, but I don't have anything special.

>games - 90% of the games I play I can play through Linux but I like playing Halo/CoD/Siege/etc which have Linux-incompatible anti-cheat
Never encountered any problems. But there definitely are some borked games. Sadly developers don't really care for almost 2% of the gamers. I think some of the battlefield games still work despite their anticheat, so I don't know if there's something that developers could do to easily fix this.

>software - I have to use Microsoft Office and LibreOffice isn't a good alternative for me also Photoshop has no real good alternative
The first point is probably work related. I would suggest to your work place that they use non-cucked standards which both Microsoft and Libre-/Open-/OnlyOffice use. Your workplace probably won't care though.
I'm not big into photo editing but instead of ps I use gimp and Inkscape (sometimes draw.io) and they work fine. Depends on the tools you use, I guess. There's also a program in the DaVinci suite I thiink and for drawing Krita. I can't help much with that, sorry.
