posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Same reasons 99% of the world doesn't run it.

It doesn't run most software, which is what an OS is for. Yes you can hack some stuff into running, but that's only something you'll do as a teenager with too much time that feels smart for doing it. And then you'll run into 10x more bugs than on windows anyway.

desktop GNU+linux is unreliable. Very unreliable. Even if you run the most stable distros like debian, that may in and of themselves be stable, your OS functioning at all is at the mercy of the drivers and the drivers that are buggy and unreliable.
Then there's the unreliability that comes from it's architecture rather than bugs. The gnu/linux application model is just broken, where there can be version incompatibilities that can ruin your system when you install the wrong thing. Even if you don't proceed to install the incompatibility , you're still prevented from using the software you wanted to. You can't expect GNU+linux to reliably run your software like Windows or Mac does.

And it's very buggy. Again, even with the most stable distros, the drivers are super buggy breaking everything, the big important software like browsers are buggy because no one tests and cares the linux builds. Then the games and professional applications are suped buggy because you have to use a hacky combability layer.

posts.com:
tldr: Ian decided that Freenet is the name of a mission, and not software, so is hijacking the name for his new toy codenamed locutus (Now Freenet).

The community predictably flipped their shit and after a lot of complaints, Ian has agreed to let the community have the project, as long as they make a new github repo and change the name... Does 4chan have any ideas?

From the release manager:

Arne (Drak) Babenhauserheide
Your ideas for a name for a new github organization

in light of the past few weeks (you saw part of that here) Steve, David, Florent and me tried to find ways to minimize the damage to the project.

We finally got Ian to open up about other names than "Freenet Classic" (which is Freenet 0.5 and in our opinion would imply that the current Freenet is deprecated), and at the very least we’ll need a new name for the Github organization so repositories can be transferred cleanly out of the control of FPI.

So we’d like to ask you for ideas. Please post them so we can find a good name together.

Requirement are:

- no existing trademark on it (so Xnet or xnet-project suggested by TheSeeker is sadly not possible; I checked).
- sufficiently easy to understand and type — and hard to get wrong.
- should be short enough that links can be printed and shown on screenshots.
- should be no slur, no bad pun, ... (after some of the things written on devl, that needs to be said)
- should not contradict the description:
Freenet is a peer-to-peer platform for
censorship-resistant and privacy-respecting
publishing and communication.

We’re looking forward for your suggestions and discussions!

Since we need to act, we’d like to set a limit of one week to the discussion and hope that a name emerges from that. If there are several contenders afterwards, we’ll have to find a way choose one together. But at the moment we hope that the outcome will be some kind of rough consensus on a good name.

Best wishes,
Arne

I want to talk with others who want to challenge themselves and build great things. please refrain from ">>>/soc" or "MODS", most of the things I'm focusing on now involve programming and technology. things including: establishing a nicer home lab, finishing a project I want to open source, and doing more hacking. have never masturbated or are on nofap,

>>91103772
In /etc/pacman.conf you should have something like:
[core]
Include = /etc/pacman.d/mirrorlist
[extra]
Include = /etc/pacman.d/mirrorlist
[community]
Include = /etc/pacman.d/mirrorlist

And in /etc/pacman.d/mirrorlist the actual mirror.

- macbook pro 16" m2 max + 4090 desktop and use laptop for work and desktop for gaming

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91107580
If they're both new-ish devices that support MU-MIMO (part of WiFi 5 / 802.11ac wave 2), they can both have independent links to the router as long as it has enough spatial streams to cover them both at once.

If they're not, you can use a router with a fast CPU and good SQM implementation to enforce airtime fairness. Assuming your Internet is pretty fast relative to WiFi. Like Gbit+. If you're on a 10M connection and your phone and laptop can't play nice you probably have defective hardware in the mix.

FAGMAN certainly writes their explainers this way. They imply to only track you when you are signed in and you have your history enabled in the account. They mostly do not talk about the case where you are logged out.
The tech companies also track you when you are logged out. They will use whatever they can to add your activity to an existing profile. An easy example are cookies. Those are set automatically also when you are not logged in. On YouTube, when you watch videos, the recommendations will change, also when you are not signed into an account. Your IP address could change each hour, but the smart devices are always on the current IP address. They connect to the tech companies with serial numbers and embedded cookies, so the current IP address is yours.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91114231
Helps you better organize your torrents if you are seeding multiple things at a time. You could have custom rules and scripts that only apply to torrents with or without labels. For example you could have torrents labeled as seasonal only seed up to ratio 2 while having the rest stay and seed as much as you like. Right now I have all torrents I don't want to be removed in a directory called .seedbox and my routines check for all active torrents with ratio >= 2 and if there's a match they get removed. If there's no way to differentiate between stuff you want gone and stuff you want to actively seed, anything that matches will get removed. Labels are just more convenient to isolate false positives

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91114770
A list element has a value (1, "a", true) and a pointer to another list element; it doesn't contain any other list elements within itself, just a pointer to the next one.

to traverse a list you can start at the first element (the head) and follow the pointer to the next element, then use that one to get the next element, and so on. When you reach an element that doesn't point to another one that means you've reached the end of the list.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91123031
"raid is not a backup" is sometimes misunderstood
backups are often done onto a raided setup, which is fine, the phrase means you shouldn't use raid /instead of/ a backup, not that raid can't be part of your backup solution

if you have a bunch of drives, care about integrity, and this is a second copy (a backup), and not the only copy, then you should use a raid, such as zfs or btrfs
btrfs is easier and more flexible, so would suggest that unless you know you want zfs instead, zfs requires more planning and is really better suited for large setups
what raid setting to use depends on what you have and what you need
raid1 is the simplest, just stores two copies on different drives, this means you sacrifice half your space, with btrfs you can raid1 more than two drives, and still use just half the space, as btrfs raids in 1GB chunks and can spread the data across any number of disks
raid10 is also half the space, but twice the speed (roughly speaking), this raids in sets of 4 chunks, so you need at least that many disks
raid5/6 is not as scary as people make it out to be, while there's still issues with it in btrfs (such as slow scrubbing), it's extremely unlikely to explode on you, and the feared write hole is not nearly as bad as people think it is, with these you lose 1 or 2 disks worth of space respectively, so they're the most efficient space-wise, you can also gain some speed as well as disks work in parallel (btrfs will spread stripes across all available disks)

with btrfs you can change raid type at any time, so you can change your mind if one doesn't suit you anymore

>How does someone go from very low level code or machine code to opening a window on your screen?
Import <windows.h> or learn the windows api for WASM. If you're not on a normal human operating system you use nuklear or something. >>91123380
Good.
Here is an overview:
Everything can be represented by numbers:
- letters: give each one a number
- words: put together a bunch of letter numbers
- images: number for each pixel

Your job as a programmer is to find out how to represent things you care about in the world as numbers and then provide operations to manipulate them. For example, once you have a bitmap you might want to scale and rotate it.

Now computers also have nice hardware that understand numbers too. So you can give your values to hardware and things happen in the world like showing you colors on the screen.

So that's basically how it works except there are lots of libraries to help you.

>>91122690
The monitor is an output device that requires data to turn into an image to display. The decoding of the data and turning it into images is done on the monitor itself, but the data is provided by the cpu or gpu.
You don't really need to know how the monitor works as a programmer.
As a programmer you don't typically need to know how the GPU works either, you just need to know what and how data is sent to it efficiently so it can crunch numbers in time to keep a steady stream of output to the monitor. If you really want to you can use an open gl library in C and make some triangles or something and you should start to understand how plotting lines and colors and pixels work

first you are mixing stuff up. understand the structure, the division.
you do understand what graphics are right?
that the computer can "render" shapes, convert them to something a display screen can understand and send that to it. thats graphics. that how you can see ur browser window.
the reason you can send data across the internet is because of your wifi card, your program sends the data it wants to send to a file in the linux OS, and the kernel takes that data and sends it to the card, and tells it what to do with it. same way for reading data.
you know how a program works right? starting with a executable, it is machine code, that the cpu can directly understand, however if you are running it through your OS, your kernel will restrict it in ways, like not allowing it to some files or something other than that, the cpu is just running the instruction one after the other.
you get an executable using a compiler which is another exectuable. the compiler converts text to something it can understand(by removing the syntax) to something it can convert to machine code.
your browser does this live, and converts code it recieves over the internet to that graphical thing you can see. now that you have a basic/ crude understanding, you can reasearch more about this. also try using chatgpt instead of 4chan to ask questions.
